paragraphs.text: EEOC: School wrong to fire teacher who gave Bible to student.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: A New Jersey school district violated the law when it fired a teacher who handed a Bible to a student
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the U.S  Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled on December 15, 2014
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The ruling was made public Tuesday
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The EEOC determined there was reasonable cause to believe the Phillipsburg School District discriminated against Walt Tutka, a substitute teacher
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The EEOC also said religion and retaliation played a factor in Tutka's firing
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This is a great indication the EEOC is taking religious liberty seriously and they are going to enforce the law-- and in this case make sure Walt's rights are protected," Liberty Institute attorney Hiram Sasser told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Liberty Institute is a law firm that specializes in religious liberty cases
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: "This sends a message to school districts that their natural allergic reaction to religion is misplaced, and not only is it wrong-- but it's also an egregious violation of the law," Sasser said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As I first reported, Tutka was working as a substitute teacher on Oct  12, 2013
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when he ran afoul of school policies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He told a straggling student at the end of a line, "The first shall be last and the last shall be first."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The student asked on a number of occasions where the line was from
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Tutka told him it was from the Bible
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: When
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he discovered the child did not have a Bible
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Tutka gave him his personal copy
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was not all that unusual
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because Tutka is a member of Gideons International, a ministry known for providing Bibles to school children across the world
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On Oct  18, Tutka was summoned to the principal's office
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: where he was accused of violating a school policy that bans the distribution of religious materials and another that directs teachers to be neutral when discussion religious material
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He was fired on Jan  14
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Sasser said he hopes the school district will reinstate Tutka
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "If they don't do the right thing, they will face some serious consequences," he told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "They are going to be liable for damages."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I reached out to George Chando, the superintendent of the Phillipsburg School District
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He declined to return my call
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: My advice to him is to do the right thing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: or
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Liberty Institute will go after him like a pit bull going after a pork chop
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Sasser said the EEOC ruling should serve as a warning to other school districts around the nation
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "You can't just fire people because they happen to hand a Bible to somebody while they are at work," he said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Sasser said he believes the school district was out to get Walt because he is a Gideon
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I obtained a copy of an email from Phillipsburg Middle School Assistant Principal John Stillo that suggest the school district had an issue with the well-known religious group
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "It has been brought to the administration's attention that Gideons may be near our campus to distribute literature to our students," Stillo wrote in a memo to the school's staff
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Please make sure they DO NOT step foot onto our campus at any time. There will be added police and security presence at dismissal."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Gideon International has a long history of providing Bibles to public school students
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: many districts have banned the religious society in recent years
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Ironically, the Gideons are welcome to distribute Bibles and deliver speeches in Russian schools
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Phillipsburg School District should rehire Walt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And it owes him a big apology
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They waged a disgusting public war against this fine, upstanding man simply because he gave a child a Bible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Shame on you, Phillipsburg School District
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Shame on you
paragraphs.label: no-unit
